text: Informed Trading of Out-of-the-Money Options and * Market Efficiency Chang-Mo Kang(cid:132) Donghyun Kim(cid:133) Junyong Kim§ Geul Lee¶ Abstract We examine stock return predictability of “Out-of-The-Money (OTM) put-to-OTM call trading volume ratio” (OTMPC). Our numerical analysis predicts that, in the U.S. equity option market, informed investors hardly write OTM options because the leverage effect is not sufficient to compensate for transaction costs. OTMPC, thus, captures the informed investors’ OTM put purchase volume relative to their OTM call purchase volume. After controlling for the existing empirical proxies for informed op- tion trading, we find that OTMPC predicts future stock returns and corporate news. The return predictability offers implementable stock portfolio strategies. Our find- ings suggest that market inefficiency can emerge from uninformed investors’ limited knowledge about how transaction costs influence the trading strategies of informed investors. Keywords: Options, return predictability, trading volume. JEL classification: G11, G12, G13, G14. *This work was supported by the research fund of Hanyang University (HY- 202000000000515). We thank Kingsley Fong, Xing Han, Gi Ho Jeong, Jungmu Kim, Dong-Hoon Shin, Wing Wah Tham, Qinghai Wang, Pradeep Yadav, Wenrui Zhang and seminar participants at University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, 2016 Optionmetrics Research Conference, 2016 Financial Research Network Annual Meeting, 2016 Conference on Asia-Pacific Financial Markets, 2016 Australasian Finance and Baking Conference, 2016 Auckland Finance Meeting,2016KoreaDerivativesAssociationAutumnMeeting,2016FinancialInformationSocietyofKorea Annual Meeting for valuable comments and suggestions. This paper supersedes the earlier versions entitled “Stock return predictability of out-of-the-money option trading” and “Market segmentation of stock and options.” (cid:132)Department of Finance, School of Business, Hanyang University, Seoul, South Korea, cmkang@hanyang.ac.kr, Phone: +82-2-2220-2587 (cid:133)Chung-Ang University, School of Business Administration, Email: donghyunkim@cau.ac.kr, Phone: +82-2-820-5657 §Lubar Business School, University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, Email: junyong@uwm.edu ¶Coinplug Inc., Email: glee@coinplug.com, Phone: +82-10-4678-5582 1 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=2803724

text: 1 Introduction The role of option contracts in financial market efficiency has been a long-standing issue in financial economics. Options can enhance the market efficiency by providing investors with more contingencies or by relaxing market frictions such as the leverage constraints of investors or the stock short-selling constraints (Black 1975, Ross 1976, Easley et al. 1998). Consistent with this insight, a number of empirical studies reported evidence of stock price discovery function of options markets.1 Some of these studies found that the information contained in option trading volume or implied volatilities is slowly incorporated into the underlying stock prices.2 In this paper, we develop a novel empirical measure that extracts information from publicly available option trading data and investigate the responsiveness of stock prices to the information. Our study innovates the literature by considering how the option market conditions, such as margin requirements and transaction costs (i.e., bid-ask spreads), affect the informed trading activities. Specifically, we show that more precise information can be obtained from the trading volume or the change in open interests of certain classes of options that require high margins and transaction costs. As it turns out, the information contained in our measure is not captured by the existing trading volume-based or price-based measures and, furthermore, is slowly diffused into the stock market. Our study thus extends the understanding of information diffusion between options and stock markets and provides novelevidencethatthemarketinefficiencycanemergefromtheuninformedinvestors’limited 1See, e.g., Manaster and Rendleman (1982), Vijh (1988), Anthony (1988), Conrad (1989), Stephan and Whaley (1990), Mayhew et al. text: knowledge about how the market conditions influence the trading strategies of informed investors. Our methodology is built on the stylized fact that bid-ask spreads and margin require- ments vary with the moneyness of options. Specifically, previous studies reported that, in the US equity options market, investors are subject to higher bid-ask spreads and margin requirements for out-of-the-money (OTM) option trades than near-the-money (NTM) or in-the-money (ITM) option trades.3 Given these institutional features, cash-constrained in- formed investors who have private information about the fundamental value of underlying stock would trade OTM options only if the leverage effect of OTM option trading is suffi- ciently high to compensate for the transaction costs. Using a numerical analysis, we show that informed trades of OTM options are more skewed to long strategies than those of NTM or ITM options. While long OTM option strategies can provide sufficiently high returns to informed investors if they predict a large stock price change, short OTM option strategies yield lower returns net of transaction costs than other option trading strategies because the leverage effect for writing OTM options is curtailed by the higher margin requirements. The analysis results provide a number of testable hypotheses. First, our analysis sug- gests that “OTM put-to-call trading volume ratio (OTMPC vol)” captures the informed investors’ OTM put purchase volume relative to their OTM call purchase volume because the seller-initiated informed OTM option trading is unlikely to occur. We also complement OTMPC vol using the change in OTM options open interest. Specifically, while the trading volume may include liquidating trades that unwind existing positions, the increase in open interest corresponds to the increase in aggregate naked positions and, thus, may capture net 3See, e.g., Jameson and Wilhelm (1992), George and Longstaff (1993), and Chakravarty et al. text: purchases of informed investors better. Motivated by this insight, we use “OTM Put-to-Call open interest increment ratio (OTMPC oi)” as an alternative proxy for the informed OTM option trades. Next, our analysis suggests that higher OTMPC ratios would predict lower stock returns if the information contained in OTM option trading is slowly diffused into the stock market. Finally, our analysis shows that, because of high transaction costs, the informed traders purchase OTM calls (resp. OTM puts) only if they predict a large increase (resp. decrease) in the future stock price. We, thus, hypothesize that higher (resp. lower) OTMPC ratios predict a price crash (resp. a price surge) of underlying stock. Before presenting the empirical findings, it is noteworthy that our study is novel in the large body of literature about multi-market information diffusion. Black (1975) provides insight that high leverage effect of long OTM option strategies induces informed investors to purchase OTM options prior to placing other option trades, but the subsequent empiri- cal studies find that informed traders are more likely to purchase NTM options because of transaction costs (e.g., Cao et al. 2005 and Augustin et al. 2017) and that they also write options (Pan and Poteshman 2006). By considering the interaction of transaction costs, margin requirements and leverage effect of option trading, we explain why attentive public investors can obtain more precise information from the trading volume or the open interest of OTM options though informed trading may occur more actively in NTM options markets. Specifically, our analysis shows that informed investors hardly write OTM options and pur- chase them only if they expect sufficiently large stock price changes. While the informed investors may trade NTM options more frequently, the lack of informed OTM option writing allows OTMPC ratios to capture the informed trading activities more precisely than the corresponding measures of NTM options. text: formation relative to other option market measures proposed by previous studies. Most studies do not focus on the OTM option trading mainly because of relatively low trading volume. An exception is the work of Xing et al. (2010). They predict that investors may buy OTM puts after acquiring bad news about the underlying stock and that, as suggested by the demand-based option pricing model (Gaˆrleanu et al. 2008), the informed OTM put purchases may create the implied volatility smirk. Consistent with this prediction, they find that the smirk is negatively associated with future stock returns. Relative to their measure, OTMPC can provide novel information in three aspects: First, recent studies show that the return predictability of the implied volatility smirk is associated with the stock market liquidity shocks (Goncalves-Pinto et al. 2020) or the stock borrowing fees (Muravyev et al. 2018). By contrast, OTMPC is a trading volume-based measure and thus less likely to be influenced by these stock market factors. Furthermore, OTMPC can also capture the posi- tive information contained in OTM call trading. Finally, while the implied volatility smirk is negatively associated with the underlying stock return positive skewness, OTMPC does not haveamechanicalrelationshipwithit. Rather, wefindthatOTMPCishigherforovervalued lottery-like stocks (i.e., stocks with positively skewed returns), suggesting that it captures OTM put purchases of informed investors rather than skewness preference of uninformed investors. Using the U.S. equity options trading data, we first examine the stock return predictabil- ityofmonthlyOTMPCratiosandreportthreemainfindings. We further refine OTMPC ratios by excluding the trading volume and open interest changes of OTM options that fall into ATM or ITM by the end of the calendar month. Notice that the information contained in the purchases of these options has been substantially incorporated into the price within the trading calendar month. The refined OTMPC ratios exhibit stronger return predictabilities that remain statistically significant for two months. We also find that, as suggested by our numerical analysis, higher (resp. lower) OTMPC ratios predict the occurrence of a stock price crash (resp. surge) in the following month. The return predictability of monthly OTMPC ratios provides an implementable portfolio strategy. Anequalweightedlong-shortstrategythatbuysabottomdecileportfolioofrefined monthly OTMPC vol and short-sells a top decile portfolio offers 0.88% of monthly 4-factor alpha, equivalently, 10.6%annualalpha. Avalue-weightedlong-shortstrategyofbottomand top decile portfolios yields 0.75% of monthly alpha, equivalently, 9% annual alpha. Refined monthly OTMPC oi offers even more profitable portfolio strategies. A long-short strategy of equal-weighted (resp. value-weighted) bottom and top decile portfolios earn 0.90% (resp. 0.86%) of monthly alpha, equivalently, 10.8% (resp. 10.3%) annual alpha. Finally, we examine the presence of informed OTM option trading around two material corporate events, i.e., earnings announcements and M&A announcements, to understand the information contents of OTMPC ratios.4 Regarding earnings announcements, our monthly Fama and MacBeth (1973) regression shows that higher (resp. lower) OTMPC ratios in a month ahead of earning announcements predict a negative (resp. positive) earnings sur- prise. text: ment month. The findings suggest that OTMPC rations indeed contain undisclosed material information about the firm value. This paper contributes to the literature of information diffusion between stock and option markets. A strand of literature has studied whether the information contained in publicly available option trading volume predicts the future stock returns. Using the signed option trading volume estimated by Lee and Ready (1991) algorithm, Cao et al. (2005) find signifi- cant stock return predictability around the takeover announcement period but not in normal times, and Pan and Poteshman (2006) find stock return predictability only for the following two trading days. Our paper shows that, by considering the moneyness of traded options, stronger and more persistent return predictability can be obtained from publicly observable unsigned option trading volume. Johnson and So (2012) show that a long-lived stock return predictability can be obtained by using stock and option trading volumes together. They find that the ratio of option trading volume to stock trading volume (O/S) is negatively associated with the weekly future stock returns. While they also use publicly observable trading volume data, our paper differs from their study in several aspects. First, the information contained in our option trading volume measure is not captured by their O/S measure. Furthermore, while their economic mechanism suggests that the return predictability of O/S measure arises from negative information about underlying stocks, we show that OTMPC contains both positive and negative information. Our study is also closely related to Augustin et al. (2017). They consider the effect of option transaction costs on the“bang-for-the-buck” strategy of informed investors and show that the investors are less likely to trade OTM options. text: option trading volume by considering the effect of transaction costs on both long and short option strategies.5 Finally, another strand of literature finds stock return predictability of option price-based measures (e.g., Cremers and Weinbaum 2010, Xing et al. 2010 and An et al. 2014). While these findings can be interpreted as evidence of slow information diffusion between option and stock markets, Goncalves-Pinto et al. (2020) and Muravyev et al. (2018) show that they can be also related to the stock market liquidity shocks to the stock borrowing fees. By using option trading volume, our study addresses this concern and provides convincing evidence of slow information diffusion between the two markets. The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 studies the effect of option transaction costs on trading strategies of informed investors and develops testing hypotheses. Section 3 de- scribesthedataandprovidessummarystatisticsofOTMPCandotherkeyvariables. Section 4 presents evidence of return predictability of OTMPC. Section 5 develops implementable portfolio strategies using the return predictability of OTMPC. Section 6 presents the results of robustness checks, and Section 7 concludes. 2 Hypothesis development: transaction costs and in- formed option trading In this section, we examine how the margin requirements and the transaction costs (i.e., bid- ask spreads) influence the option trading strategy of a cash-constrained informed investors who have private information about the fundamental value of underlying stock. text: cussed below, our analysis proposes a novel empirical measure that captures the information contained in option trading activities. Specifically, we focus on the informed trading of OTM options. Previous studies report that both margin requirements and bid-ask spreads increase with the out-of-the-moneyness of options in the U.S. equity option markets. Jameson and Wilhelm (1992), George and Longstaff (1993), and Chakravarty et al. (2004) report that bid-ask spreads of OTM options tend to be wider than those of NTM or ITM options. Regarding the margin requirement of US option exchanges, Santa-Clara and Saretto (2009) report that OTM option writers are required to maintain higher margins than NTM or ITM option writers. A cash-constrained informed investors would trade OTM options only if the leverage effect of OTM option trading is sufficiently high to compensate for the transaction costs. We predict that informed traders of OTM options are more skewed to buyers relative to sellers than those of NTM or ITM options. That is, the informed investors who predict a stock price increase (resp. decrease) rarely write OTM puts (resp. OTM calls). Informed investors may buy OTM options if they predict a large change in stock prices because the leverage effect of long option strategies tends to increase with the out-of-the-moneyness of options. On the other hand, the higher margin requirements for OTM options curtail the leverage effect of writing OTM options and, thus, make the informed investors favor to write NTM or ITM options. We illustrate our intuition using a simple numerical analysis. Consider a market in which European options are traded with bid-ask spreads. Note that the denominator µ(P0,S)−P0 corresponds to the amount of cash that the investor should deposit as the initial margin for writing puts. Before discussing the effect of bid-ask spreads and margin constraints on the profitabil- ity of informed option trading strategies, it is noteworthy that, in the absence of margin requirement (i.e., µ(P0,S) = P0) and bid-ask spreads, informed investors can relax their cash constraint and lever up their investments unlimitedly by writing options. This observa- tion suggests that, given sufficiently low margin requirements, writing options can be more profitable than buying them to cash-constrained informed investors. Figure 1 illustrates how the profits of informed option trading strategies are influenced by margin requirements and bid-ask spreads. Panels (a)–(c) show how the expected returns of informed option trading strategies change with the out-of-the-moneyness, i.e., K for calls S and S for puts. In all numerical analysis, we set the parameter values to S = 30, σ = 0.4, K r = 0.03, t = 20/250, ∆ = 0.05 and p = 0.3.7 Panel (a) presents how the expected returns from buying calls and those from writing puts change with the moneyness when bid-ask spreads (resp. margin requirements) are set to zero (resp. 10% of Black-Scholes put price P0). The expected returns of both long and short strategies increase with the out-of- the-moneyness of call options, implying that the leverage effect of informed option trading strategies is positively associated with the out-of-the-moneyness. Furthermore, short option strategies yield higher returns than long strategies because of low margin requirements. Panel (b) considers the CBOE margin requirement and zero bid-ask spreads. Compared with Panel (b), it shows that the spreads substantially reduce the expected return from buying or writing OTM options. Given the expected large change in stock price (∆ = 0.05), buying OTM calls (e.g., the calls with K ∈ [1.05,1.1]) still yields S higher expected returns than buying NTM calls, but writing puts with the corresponding out-of-the-moneyness is not profitable. Panel (d) presents how the optimal out-of-moneynesses of calls and puts for informed in- vestors (i.e., the options that yield highest expected returns from informed trading) change with ∆. All other parameter values including the bid-ask spreads and the margin require- ments are set to the same as those in Panel (c). Informed investors can obtain higher returns from buying OTM calls than buying NTM calls when they expect a large increase in the stock price. Writing OTM puts, on the other hand, underperforms writing NTM puts for all parameter ranges of ∆ ∈ [0.03,0.1]. Figure 1 echoes our intuition. While the transaction costs substantially reduce the ex- pected returns from informed OTM option trading, informed investors may still buy OTM options to employ the leverage effect if they anticipate a large change in the stock price. The investors are unlikely to write OTM options because the leverage effect curtailed by higher margin requirements is not sufficient to compensate for the transaction costs. Our analysis provides a number of testable predictions: First, since informed traders of OTM options are more likely to be skewed to buyers, we predict that higher (resp. lower) OTM puts trading volume relative to OTM calls trading volume contains negative (reps. positive) information about the underlying stock price, in particular, about a large decrease 13 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=2803724

text: (resp. increase) in the stock price. As a proxy for informed OTM option trading activities, however, the OTM puts-to-call trading volume ratio may be noisy partly because trading volume includes liquidating trades that unwind existing positions. To filter out the liquidat- ing trades, we also consider the increase in open interest of OTM options that capture the informed investors’ net purchase of OTM options better. Our analysis suggests that larger (resp. smaller) increase in OTM puts open interest relative to OTM calls open interest includes negative (resp. positive) information about the underlying stock price. Next, iftheinformationcontainedinOTMoptiontradingactivitiesisslowlydiffusedinto the stock market, the OTM put-to-call trading volume ratio or open interest increment ratio can predict the future stock returns, in particular, a large change in stock prices because informed investors would buy OTM calls (resp. puts) only if they predict a large increase (resp. decrease) in underlying stock prices. In sum: Hypothesis. Consider OTM put-to-call (OTMPC) trading volume ratio and open interest increment ratio. 1. Higher OTMPC ratios precede a negative news about the underlying stock. 2. Higher OTMPC ratios predict lower stock returns if the information is slowly diffused into the stock market. 3. The return predictability of OTMPC ratios, if any, is more pronounced for a large change in the future stock price. text: induces informed investors to purchase OTM options prior to placing other option trades. Empirical studies, however, find that informed investors are more likely to buy NTM options than OTM options (e.g., Cao et al. 2005 and Augustin et al. 2017) and also write options (Pan and Poteshman 2006). By considering transaction costs, margin requirements and the leverage effect of option trading in tandem, our analysis shows that informed investors hardly write OTM options and purchase them only if they expect sufficiently large stock pricechanges. Notably,wedonotpredictthatinformedtradingoccursmostfrequentlyinthe OTM option market because informed investors would trade NTM options if they anticipate a small change in the stock price. While informed trading of NTM options may occur more frequently, the lack of informed OTM option writing makes OTMPC ratios capture the informed trading activities more precisely than the corresponding ratios of NTM options which may include both informed purchases and sales. 3 Data and variables We use five datasets in this study. From the IvyDB OptionMetrics database, we collect information about individual equity options such as maturity date, strike price, daily closing quotes, trading volume, implied volatility and option delta. The number of shares outstand- ing, daily stock price, and stock trading volume are obtained from the Center for Research in Security Prices (CRSP) database, and financial/accounting information from the Com- pustat database. Finally, we retrieve information about takeover announcements from the SDC Platinum Financial Securities database and analyst earnings forecast from the Thom- son Reuters I/B/E/S. All variables are described in Appendix. Our sample period spans from 1996 to 2015. 15 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=2803724

text: Following Johnson and So (2012), we employ the following data filters to reduce the measurement error associated with illiquidity of option markets: first, for each trading date, we include only option contracts that do not expire within the calendar month and that have an absolute delta between 0.02 and 0.98; then, we exclude the firm-months in which less than 50 call and 50 put contracts are traded, or in which the close stock price goes below five dollars. Our final sample for the main analysis consists of 356,541 firm-months for 5,226 unique firms.8 Relative to the CRSP universe, our sample stocks are larger and more glamorous over the sample period mainly because we filter out penny stocks and the stocks with illiquid options.9 AsdiscussedinSection2, ourkeyexplanatoryvariablesareOTMPut-to-Calltradingvol- ume ratio (OTMPC vol) and open interest increment ratio (OTMPC oi). Following Bollen and Whaley (2004) and Ge et al. (2016), we define OTM options with respect to the option delta. Specifically, we classify a call option as OTM if 0.02 < option delta ≤ 0.375, and a put option as OTM if −0.375 < option delta ≤ −0.02. Formally, we construct monthly OTMPC vol as follows: for each option contract of stock i and month t, we first compute the sum of daily trading volume when it was OTM during the month. We then compute the monthly OTMPC vol of stock i in month t using the OTM options at the last trading day of month t as follows: Sum of OTM trading volume of puts OTMPC vol = . Given that stock short-selling constraints allow OS decile to capture the informed put purchases (Johnson and So 2012 and Ge et al. 2016), the positive correlations suggests that OTMPC ratios may capture the negative infor- mationcontainedinOSdeciles. Asshownbelow, however, OTMPCratiosinnovatethesetwo measures by extracting positive information contained in option trading as well. Regarding option price-based measures, OTMPC ratios are not significantly correlated with ∆CVOL and ∆PVOL but negatively associated with Skew and VS. To control for the correlations between these measures, we also run Fama and MacBeth (1973) regression of OTMPC ra- tios on all informed option trading measures. Table A2 in Appendix shows that OTMPC ratios are significantly associated with contemporaneous informed option trading measures, suggesting that OTMPC ratios may capture the information contained in these price-based measures. In our analysis below, we control for all existing informed option trading measures to identify the information exclusively captured by OTMPC ratios. Notably, the negative correlation between OTMPC ratios and Skew is at odds given that Skew captures negative information contained in OTM put trading (Xing et al. 2010). One possible explanation is that Skew is negatively associated with the stock return skewness. Consistent with this prediction, Table A3 in Appendix shows that lottery-like stocks, which have positively skewed returns, exhibit lower Skew but higher OTMPC. The positive cor- relation between OTMPC and stock return skewness suggests that informed investors may purchase OTM puts of overvalued lottery-like stocks.11 11See Kumar (2009) who reports the underperformance of lottery-like stock portfolio. 19 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=2803724

Overall, our results suggest that the information contained in OTMPC ratios are substantially incorporated into the stock price in the following month. 4.2 Predictability for large stock price changes We next examine whether OTMPC ratios predict a large change in the future stock price. As discussed in Section 2, informed investors are likely to purchase OTM calls (resp. OTM puts) only when they predict a sufficiently large stock price increase (resp. decrease) to compensate for the high bid-ask spreads of OTM options and to fully employ the convexity of OTM option payoffs. We thus hypothesize that OTMPC ratios predict a large stock price change. In our baseline test, we set a monthly stock return above 10% (resp. below −10%) as a threshold for the stock price surge (resp. crash).13 Specifically, for stock i and month t, we create two dummy variables that indicate the monthly stock price surge (i.e., r > 10%) i,t+1 and the price crash (i.e., r < −10%), respectively. text: 5 Portfolio analysis In this section, we propose an implementable investment strategy that exploits the informa- tion contained in monthly OTMPC ratios, in particular, the refined measures. Specifically, we first sort the stocks into deciles based on their monthly rOTMPC ratios in month t, and calculate the monthly excess return and Carhart (1997) four factors alpha of each decile portfolio in month t+1. We also examine the profitability of long-short strategies that use the decile portfolios. Panel A in Table 5 reports the monthly excess returns and alphas of rOTMPC decile portfolios. Column (1) shows that the equal-weighted bottom decile portfolio built based on rOTMPC vol yields 1.36% monthly excess return while the top decile portfolio earns 0.56%. The long-short strategy that buys bottom decile portfolio and short-sells top decile portfolio on a monthly basis, therefore, yields 0.81% monthly returns, equivalently, 9.68% per annum. Column (2) shows that the long-short strategy of value-weighted bottom and top decile portfolios earns 0.65% monthly excess return, equivalently, 7.74% per annum. Columns (3) and (4) present the four factor alphas of equal-weighted and value-weighted decile portfolios, respectively. The long-short strategy of equal-weighted bottom and top decile portfolios earn 10.59% annual alpha while that of value-weighted portfolios yield 8.97% annual alpha. It is noteworthy that the long-short strategies yield higher returns from long positions (i.e., bottom decile) rather than short positions and, thus, they are relatively robust to the stock short-selling constraints. Overall, the results confirm that the information contained in OTMPC ratios is still slowly diffused into the stock market in the recent period after the financial crisis. 6.2 Corporate news predictability of OTMPC Finally, we examine whether OTMPC ratios change before the major corporate events, namely, earnings surprises and M&A announcements. Previous studies (e.g., Cao et al. 2005, Hu 2014, Augustin et al. 2017) report that informed option trading occurs before these announcements. Notably, the two events differ in the regularity of occurrence and in the direction of stock market reaction. While M&A announcements occur irregularly and are mostly accompanied with positive market reaction for target firms, earnings announcements occur regularly and can be followed by either positive or negative stock returns, depending on the ex-ante forecast of investors. text: ences in their rOTMPC ratios before M&A announcements. Specifically, relative to con- trol firms, target firms exhibit significantly lower (resp. higher) rOTMPC ratios since 4–5 months before the announcements. The difference in rOTMPC ratios between the two groups gets wider as it nears the announcement month. Specifically, target firms exhibit around 1–2% lower rOTMPC ratios over the four months before the announcement. After the announcement, the difference in rOTMPC ratios between target and matched firms flips mainly because of the market reaction to the announcement. Specifically, target firms have 2–3% higher rOTMPC ratios in the announcement month and the following two months. The results suggest that informed OTM option trading tends to occur before the M&A announcements. 7 Conclusion This paper examines the information contained in OTM option trading activities and in- vestigates how quickly the information is impounded into the underlying stock prices. Our numerical analysis shows that, in the U.S. option markets, the investors who have directional information about the future stock price rarely write OTM options because the leverage ef- fect curtailed by tighter margin requirements is not sufficient to compensate for transaction costs. Our analysis also suggests that put-to-call trading volume ratio of OTM options (OTMPC) can be used as a proxy for informed OTM option trading. We find strong evi- dence that the information contained in this measure is slowly diffused into the stock market. Higher OTMPC predicts lower future stock returns in a monthly horizon. The return pre- dictability offers implementable portfolio strategies. We also find that OTMPC predicts the future corporate events such as M&A or earnings surprises. text: Appendix Variable definitions and more results Table A1: Variable definitions Thistableprovidesabriefdescriptionofthevariablesusedinthisstudy. Variablesaresortedinalphabetical order. Variable name Description ∆ open interest Monthly open interest increment. We first find the monthly sum of daily changes in + open interest for each option contract in the month. We then compute a net “increase” in open interest of each contract. OTMPC vol (Sum of OTM puts trading volume) / (Sum of OTM options trading volume), for which OTM options satisfy 0.02 <option delta≤ 0.375 for calls and −0 : 375 <option delta≤ −0 : 02 for puts. Sum is monthly aggregate of the daily trading volume, that satisfy the moneyness condition on the day, in the month. OTMPC oi (Sum of OTM puts ∆ open interest) / (Sum of OTM options ∆ open interest), for + + which OTM options satisfy 0.02 <option delta≤ 0.375 for calls and −0.375 <option delta≤ −0.02 for puts. Sum is monthly aggregate of the daily ∆ open interest, that + satisfy the moneyness condition on the day, in the month. rOTMPC vol (Sum of OTM puts trading volume) / (Sum of OTM options trading volume), for which OTM options satisfy 0.02 <option delta≤ 0.375 for calls and −0 : 375 <option delta≤ −0 : 02 for puts. Sum is monthly aggregate of the daily trading volume, that satisfy the moneyness condition on the day, in the month. We exclude the options that fall into NTM or ITM on the last trading day of each month. rOTMPC oi (Sum of OTM puts ∆ open interest) / (Sum of OTM options ∆ open interest), for + + which OTM options satisfy 0.02 <option delta≤ 0.375 for calls and −0.375 <option delta≤ −0.02 for puts. Sum is monthly aggregate of the daily ∆ open interest, that + satisfy the moneyness condition on the day, in the month. We exclude the options that fall into NTM or ITM on the last trading day of each month. AITMPC (Sum of puts trading volume (∆ open interest)) / (Sum of options trading volume + (∆ open interest)), for which OTM options satisfy 0.5 <option delta≤ 0.98 for calls + and−0.98<optiondelta≤−0.5forputs. Sumismonthlyaggregateofthedaily∆ open + interest (volume). OS decile OS is the option volume to stock volume ratio as in Johnson and So (2012). OS decile is collected monthly. 1st (10th) decile contains options with the lowest (highest) OS. Skew The difference between the implied volatilities of OTM puts and ATM calls in Xing et al. (2010). VS Volatility spread, defined as the aggregated difference between call and put implied volatilities for same maturity and strike price, in Cremers and Weinbaum (2010). ∆CVOL Monthly change in the implied volatility of at-the-money call with time to maturity of 30 calendar days. ∆PVOL Monthly change in the implied volatility of at-the-money put with time to maturity of 30 calendar days. OTM puts) pay-off to the current stock price, whose value is max(ret −0.1, 0) (resp. (max(−0.1−ret , 0))). The main independent t+1 t+1 variables are monthly demeaned and normal OTMPC. OTMPC vol (OTMPC oi) is defined as OTM put trading volume (∆ open interest) divided by OTM option trading volume (∆ open interest). The control variables are further described in Appendix A. t-statistics are shown in parentheses. text: Table OA3: OTMPC and earnings surprises This table reports the regression results of earnings surprise on OTMPC. The dependent variables are SUE and CAR(0,5). SUE is the standard unexplained earnings calculated based on IBES reported AF AF analyst forecasts and actual EPS. CAR(i,j) is the cumulative benchmark-adjusted return in the trading day window (t + i,t + j) centered at the earnings announcement date t. Value-weighted return of size and book-to-market quintile matched stocks is used as benchmark. The main independent variables are monthly OTMPC. OTMPC vol (OTMPC oi) is defined as OTM put trading volume (∆ open interest) + divided by total OTM option trading volume (∆ open interest). All regressions include OS decile, Short + interest, ∆CVOL, ∆PVOL, VS, and Skew. Model 1–4 include the log(firm size), log(book-to-market ratio), momentum measure, Amihud (2002) illiquidity measure, and lagged monthly return of the corresponding firm or stock as control variables. The control variables are further described in Appendix A. t-statistics are shown in parentheses, and are based on Newey and West (1987) adjusted standard errors with four-month lags. ***, **, and * represent significance at the 1%, 5%, and 10% levels, respectively.
